The right use of a checked-in ignore file is to only cover the things
to ignore that are specific to that repo (build products, etc.). Users
should use a per-user ignore file for things like editor temporary
files.

For Mercurial,
  (1) Add this to your ~/.hgrc:
    [ui]
    ignore = ~/.hgignore
  (2) Put whatever globs you want in there to suit your editor.

For Git,
  (1) Add this to your ~/.gitconfig:
    [core]
            excludesfile = ~/.gitignore
  (2) Put whatever globs you want in there to suit your editor.


However, it is very common for the common exclusions to appear in a
.hgignore file in the repo so that N users don't have to do exactly
the same thing locally.
